bitmark:
[.book]
[@id:218303]
[@externalId:e-pronomen_cvbgdigfw0x0]
[#Pronomen]
[@language:de]
[@coverImage:https://docs.bitmark.cloud/bit-books/englisch-hilfen/web-resources/images/englischhilfen_grammatik_cover.png]

[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218304]
[%Nr. 3124]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Objektform der englischen Personalpronomen aus.]

1. I → [-her][-him][-it][+me][-them][-us][-you]
2. you → [-her][-him][-it][-me][-them][-us][+you]
3. he → [-her][+him][-it][-me][-them][-us][-you]
4. she → [+her][-him][-it][-me][-them][-us][-you]
5. it → [-her][-him][+it][-me][-them][-us][-you]
6. we → [-her][-him][-it][-me][-them][+us][-you]
7. they → [-her][-him][-it][-me][+them][-us][-you]

bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Objektform der englischen Personalpronomen aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice:bitmark--]
[@id:218305]
[%Nr. 3134]
[!Welche Objektform des Personalpronomens kann man für den unterstrichenen Satzteil einsetzen?]

===
[!1. The teacher always gives __the students__ homework.]
[-me]
[+them]
[-you]
===
[!2. I am reading the book to __my little sister__.]
[+her]
[-us]
[-him]
===
[!3. The boys are riding on __their bikes__.]
[-it]
[+them]
[-her]
===
[!4. My father is writing a letter to __John__.]
[-me]
[-her]
[+him]
===
[!5. I don't know __the answer__.]
[-she]
[-her]
[+it]
===
[!6. Sally is going to see __Anne__.]
[+her]
[-him]
[-me]
===
[!7. Open __the window__, please.]
[+it]
[-them]
[-us]
===
[!8. Can you tell __the people__ the way to the airport, please?]
[-you]
[+them]
[-us]
===
[!9. The books are for __Peter__.]
[+him]
[-her]
[-you]
===
[!10. Can you help __my sister and me__, please?]
[-her]
[-me]
[+us]
===

bit.instruction: Welche Objektform des Personalpronomens kann man für den unterstrichenen Satzteil einsetzen?

quizzes.instruction: 1. The teacher always gives __the students__ homework.
2. I am reading the book to __my little sister__.
3. The boys are riding on __their bikes__.
4. My father is writing a letter to __John__.
8. Can you tell __the people__ the way to the airport, please?
10. Can you help __my sister and me__, please?

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218306]
[%Nr. 3110]
[!Setze die richtigen Personalpronomen in die Lücken ein. Die Wörter in Klammern helfen dir dabei.]

0. [_She][@example] often reads books. (Lisa)
1. [_He][!George] is dreaming.
2. [_It][!the blackboard] is green.
3. [_They][!the posters] are on the wall.
4. [_It][!the dog] is running.
5. [_We][!my mother and I] are watching TV.
6. [_They][!the flowers] are in the garden.
7. [_He][!Tom] is riding his bike.
8. [_She][!Victoria] is from Bristol.
9. [_She][!Diana] has got a brother.
10. Have [_you] got a computer, Mandy?

bit.body:
0. {0} often reads books. (Lisa)
1. {1} is dreaming.
2. {2} is green.
3. {3} are on the wall.
4. {4} is running.
5. {5} are watching TV.
6. {6} are in the garden.
7. {7} is riding his bike.
8. {8} is from Bristol.
9. {9} has got a brother.
10. Have {10} got a computer, Mandy?
bit.instruction: Setze die richtigen Personalpronomen in die Lücken ein. Die Wörter in Klammern helfen dir dabei.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218307]
[%Nr. 3112]
[!Wähle das richtige Personalpronomen aus.]

1. [+I][-They][-You] am sitting on the sofa.
2. [-He][+We][-It] are watching TV.
3. Are [-he][-she][+you] from England?
4. [-I][+He][-We] is going home.
5. [+They][-I][-She] are playing football.
6. [-He][-We][+It] is a wonderful day today.
7. [-She][+We][-I] are speaking English.
8. Is [+she][-he][-you] Kevin's sister?
9. [-I][-She][+You] are swimming in the pool.
10. Are [-I][-She][+They] in the cinema?

bit.body:
1. {0} am sitting on the sofa.
2. {1} are watching TV.
3. Are {2} from England?
4. {3} is going home.
5. {4} are playing football.
6. {5} is a wonderful day today.
7. {6} are speaking English.
8. Is {7} Kevin's sister?
9. {8} are swimming in the pool.
10. Are {9} in the cinema?
bit.instruction: Wähle das richtige Personalpronomen aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218308]
[%Nr. 3114]
[!Ersetze die Substantive durch die richtigen Personalpronomen und schreibe diese in die Lücken ein.]


0. uncle → [_he][@example]
1. sister → [_she]
2. boy → [_he]
3. school → [_it]
4. cars → [_they]
5. Emily and Jack → [_they]
6. bike → [_it]
7. Sophia and I → [_we]
8. dad → [_he]
9. parents → [_they]
10. teacher → [_he]

bit.instruction: Ersetze die Substantive durch die richtigen Personalpronomen und schreibe diese in die Lücken ein.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218309]
[%Nr. 3168]
[!Setze die richtigen Personalpronomen in die Lücken ein.]

0. Where is my umbrella?
[_It][@example] is in the corner.
1. This is Henry.
[_He] comes from Scotland.
2. Look at Jack and Susan.
[_They] are walking.
3. What time is it?
[_It] is 10 o'clock.
4. There are two dogs.
[_They] are brown and white.
5. Where is Lisa?
[_She] is in town.
6. How are you?
[_I] am fine.
7. This is a football.
[_It] is blue and white.
8. Where are my glasses?
[_They] are on the table.
9. Here are Doris and me.
[_We] are sitting on the wall.
10. Where am I?
[_You] are here.

bit.body:
0. Where is my umbrella?
{0} is in the corner.
1. This is Henry.
{1} comes from Scotland.
2. Look at Jack and Susan.
{2} are walking.
3. What time is it?
{3} is 10 o'clock.
4. There are two dogs.
{4} are brown and white.
5. Where is Lisa?
{5} is in town.
6. How are you?
{6} am fine.
7. This is a football.
{7} is blue and white.
8. Where are my glasses?
{8} are on the table.
9. Here are Doris and me.
{9} are sitting on the wall.
10. Where am I?
{10} are here.
bit.instruction: Setze die richtigen Personalpronomen in die Lücken ein.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218310]
[%Nr. 3162]
[!Setze das Personalpronomen in Klammern entweder in der **Subjektform** oder der **Objektform** ein.]

0. We gave [_her][@example] a present. __(she)__
1. [_He][!he] lives in Liverpool.
2. I met [_him][!he] in the office.
3. They sing with [_me][!I] in the choir.
4. Lisa likes [_it][!it].
5. Excuse [_me][!I], is this the way to the station?
6. [_We][!we] worked in the garden.
7. Where are the cupcakes? Did you eat [_them][!they]?
8. Is [_she][!she] your sister?
9. Where are [_you][!she] from?
10. [_We][!we] saw Jack in the office.

bit.body:
0. We gave {0} a present. __(she)__
1. {1} lives in Liverpool.
2. I met {2} in the office.
3. They sing with {3} in the choir.
4. Lisa likes {4}.
5. Excuse {5}, is this the way to the station?
6. {6} worked in the garden.
7. Where are the cupcakes? Did you eat {7}?
8. Is {8} your sister?
9. Where are {9} from?
10. {10} saw Jack in the office.
bit.instruction: Setze das Personalpronomen in Klammern entweder in der **Subjektform** oder der **Objektform** ein.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218311]
[%Nr. 3116]
[!Setze die richtigen Personalpronomen oder Possessivbegleiter ein. Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.]

I am Robert and [+I][-me][-my] live in Bristol. This is Jack. [+He][-Him][-His] is [-I][-me][+my] friend. [+He][-Him][-His] lives in Bristol too. Sarah likes [-he][+him][-his]. [+She][-Her] likes [-he][-him][+his] blue eyes very much. Sarah lives with [-she][+her] older sister in a flat in Bristol. Bristol is [-we][-us][+our] hometown. [+It][-Its] is an old city with lots of sights.

bit.body: I am Robert and {0} live in Bristol. This is Jack. {1} is {2} friend. {3} lives in Bristol too. Sarah likes {4}. {5} likes {6} blue eyes very much. Sarah lives with {7} older sister in a flat in Bristol. Bristol is {8} hometown. {9} is an old city with lots of sights.
bit.instruction: Setze die richtigen Personalpronomen oder Possessivbegleiter ein. Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218312]
[%Nr. 3122]
[!Welche Possessivbegleiter passen in die Lücken? Beachte die **fett gedruckten** Wörter in den deutschen Sätzen.]

0. Das ist **unser** Haus. → This is [_our][@example] house.
1. Ist das **dein** Buch? → Is this [_your] book?
2. **Unsere** Eltern leben in Hamburg. → [_Our] parents live in Hamburg.
3. Das ist **meine** Gitarre. → This is [_my] guitar.
4. Wie alt ist **seine** Schwester? → How old is [_his] sister?
5. Wo spielt **deine** Mannschaft? → Where does [_your] team play?
6. Gestern verschickte sie **ihren** Brief nach London. → Yesterday she sent [_her] letter to London.
7. Sind das dort **eure** Turnschuhe? → Are those [_your] trainers?
8. Ken hat sich in **seinen** Finger geschnitten. → Ken has cut [_his] finger.
9. Die Kinder beendeten **ihr** Spiel. → The children finished [_their] game.
10. Das Hotel hat **sein** eigenes Schwimmbad. → The hotel has [_its] own swimming pool.

bit.body:
0. Das ist **unser** Haus. → This is {0} house.
1. Ist das **dein** Buch? → Is this {1} book?
2. **Unsere** Eltern leben in Hamburg. → {2} parents live in Hamburg.
3. Das ist **meine** Gitarre. → This is {3} guitar.
4. Wie alt ist **seine** Schwester? → How old is {4} sister?
5. Wo spielt **deine** Mannschaft? → Where does {5} team play?
6. Gestern verschickte sie **ihren** Brief nach London. → Yesterday she sent {6} letter to London.
7. Sind das dort **eure** Turnschuhe? → Are those {7} trainers?
8. Ken hat sich in **seinen** Finger geschnitten. → Ken has cut {8} finger.
9. Die Kinder beendeten **ihr** Spiel. → The children finished {9} game.
10. Das Hotel hat **sein** eigenes Schwimmbad. → The hotel has {10} own swimming pool.
bit.instruction: Welche Possessivbegleiter passen in die Lücken? Beachte die **fett gedruckten** Wörter in den deutschen Sätzen.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218313]
[%Nr. 3120]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben den richtigen Possessivbegleiter zum vorgegebenen Personalpronomen aus.]

1. I → [-her][-his][-its][+my][-our][-their][-your]
2. you → [-her][-his][-its][-my][-our][-their][+your]
3. he → [-her][+his][-its][-my][-our][-their][-your]
4. she → [+her][-his][-its][-my][-our][-their][-your]
5. it → [-her][-his][+its][-my][-our][-their][-your]
6. we → [-her][-his][-its][-my][+our][-their][-your]
7. they → [-her][-his][-its][-my][-our][+their][-your]

bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben den richtigen Possessivbegleiter zum vorgegebenen Personalpronomen aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218314]
[%Nr. 3176]
[!Welcher Possessivbegleiter fehlt in den vorgegebenen Sätzen? Beachte das __unterstrichene__ Personalpronomen.]

0. __My dad__ hurt [_his][@example] leg.
1. __Lenny__ lives in Liverpool with [_his] brother.
2. __I__ share a room with [_my] sister.
3. __Paul, Henry__ and [_their] uncle work in London.
4. __We__ are from Dublin. Peggy and Ron are [_our] neighbours.
5. __Tina__ plays handball in [_her] school.
6. __I__ like to ride [_my] bike.
7. __Joe__ loves cars. [_His] favourite one is a Ferrari.
8. __Alan__ has a guitar. [_Its] colour is black.
9. __The students__ seldom forget [_their] homework.
10. Hi __Jayden__. – Is this [_your] book?

bit.body:
0. __My dad__ hurt {0} leg.
1. __Lenny__ lives in Liverpool with {1} brother.
2. __I__ share a room with {2} sister.
3. __Paul, Henry__ and {3} uncle work in London.
4. __We__ are from Dublin. Peggy and Ron are {4} neighbours.
5. __Tina__ plays handball in {5} school.
6. __I__ like to ride {6} bike.
7. __Joe__ loves cars. {7} favourite one is a Ferrari.
8. __Alan__ has a guitar. {8} colour is black.
9. __The students__ seldom forget {9} homework.
10. Hi __Jayden__. – Is this {10} book?
bit.instruction: Welcher Possessivbegleiter fehlt in den vorgegebenen Sätzen? Beachte das __unterstrichene__ Personalpronomen.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218315]
[%Nr. 3118]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben den Possessivbegleiter (Possessivpronomen, das als Adjektiv verwendet wird) aus.]

Hi Daniel,
[+My][-Your][-His][-Her][-Our][-Their] name is John. This is [+my][-your][-his][-her][-our][-their] friend Jason. He's 12. [-My][-Your][+His][-Her][-Our][-Their] sister is nine. They have got a pet. [-My][-Your][-His][-Her][-Our][+Their] pet is a budgie. 
[-My][-Your][+His][-Her][-Our][-Their] name is Charlie. Jason and I go to the same school. There are 450 boys and girls in [-my][-your][-his][-her][+our][-their] school. Jason's form teacher is Mrs. Peterson. She has got a pet, too. [-My][-Your][-His][+Her][-Our][-Their] pet is a tortoise. Our form teacher is Mr. Smith. I like [-my][-your][+his][-her][-our][-their] lessons. He has two dogs. The dogs love to play in [-my][-your][+his][-her][-our][-their] garden. Now I have a question for you. What's [-my][+your][-his][-her][-our][-their] pet?

Yours,
John

bit.body:
Hi Daniel,
{0} name is John. This is {1} friend Jason. He's 12. {2} sister is nine. They have got a pet. {3} pet is a budgie. 
{4} name is Charlie. Jason and I go to the same school. There are 450 boys and girls in {5} school. Jason's form teacher is Mrs. Peterson. She has got a pet, too. {6} pet is a tortoise. Our form teacher is Mr. Smith. I like {7} lessons. He has two dogs. The dogs love to play in {8} garden. Now I have a question for you. What's {9} pet?

Yours,
John
bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben den Possessivbegleiter (Possessivpronomen, das als Adjektiv verwendet wird) aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218316]
[%Nr. 3164]
[!Setze für das Personalpronomen in Klammern entweder den **Possessivbegleiter** oder das **Possessivpronomen** ein.]

0. Can you come to [_our][@example] party? __(we)__
1. The bus stop is near [_our][!we] house.
2. How is [_your][!you] new school?
3. This is my bag and that is [_his][!he].
4. Sophia's hair is longer than [_mine][!I].
5. It's [_my][!I] turn now.
6. The bike on the right is [_yours][!you].
7. Which desk is [_ours][!we]?
8. Here are [_her][!she] tickets.
9. The children brushed [_their][!they] teeth.
10. Our school is much nicer than [_theirs][!they].

bit.body:
0. Can you come to {0} party? __(we)__
1. The bus stop is near {1} house.
2. How is {2} new school?
3. This is my bag and that is {3}.
4. Sophia's hair is longer than {4}.
5. It's {5} turn now.
6. The bike on the right is {6}.
7. Which desk is {7}?
8. Here are {8} tickets.
9. The children brushed {9} teeth.
10. Our school is much nicer than {10}.
bit.instruction: Setze für das Personalpronomen in Klammern entweder den **Possessivbegleiter** oder das **Possessivpronomen** ein.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218317]
[%Nr. 3126]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben das passende Possessivpronomen aus.]

1. I → [-hers][-his][-its][+mine][-ours][-theirs][-yours]
2. you → [-hers][-his][-its][-mine][-ours][-theirs][+yours]
3. he → [-hers][+his][-its][-mine][-ours][-theirs][-yours]
4. she → [+hers][-his][-its][-mine][-ours][-theirs][-yours]
5. it → [-hers][-his][+its][-mine][-ours][-theirs][-yours]
6. we → [-hers][-his][-its][-mine][+ours][-theirs][-yours]
7. they → [-hers][-his][-its][-mine][-ours][+theirs][-yours]

bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben das passende Possessivpronomen aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218318]
[%Nr. 3128]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben entweder den Possessivbegleiter oder das Possessivpronomen aus.]

1. Whose bike is this? Is it really [-him][+his]?
2. Is he [+your][-yours] teacher?
3. Hey Ron! This is not [+our][-ours] car. [-Our][+Ours] is red.
4. Lisa broke [+her][-hers] left leg.
5. This is [-mine][+my] house, where's [+theirs][-them]?
6. Is this Emily's room? – Yes, it's [-her][+hers].
7. I lost [-mine][+my] pen in the library. Can I have one of [-your][+yours]?
8. Stop! – These sweets are all [+mine][-my].
9. Did you forget to do [+your][-yours] homework yesterday? – No I didn't. I did [-mine][+my] homework.
10. Are these really [-you][+your] shoes? – Yes, these are [+my][-mine] shoes. – They are not [-you][+yours].

bit.body:
1. Whose bike is this? Is it really {0}?
2. Is he {1} teacher?
3. Hey Ron! This is not {2} car. {3} is red.
4. Lisa broke {4} left leg.
5. This is {5} house, where's {6}?
6. Is this Emily's room? – Yes, it's {7}.
7. I lost {8} pen in the library. Can I have one of {9}?
8. Stop! – These sweets are all {10}.
9. Did you forget to do {11} homework yesterday? – No I didn't. I did {12} homework.
10. Are these really {13} shoes? – Yes, these are {14} shoes. – They are not {15}.
bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben entweder den Possessivbegleiter oder das Possessivpronomen aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218319]
[%Nr. 3130]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Form aus – **Possessivbegleiter** oder **Possessivpronomen**.]

1. Is that [+your][-yours] pen? → Is it [-your][+yours]?
2. This is [-mine][+my] house. → It's [-my][+mine].
3. They're [+their][-theirs] children. → They're [-their][+theirs].
4. She lost [+her][-hers] book. → She lost [-her][+hers].
5. These are [+our][-ours] folders. → These are [-our][+ours].
6. I like [-mine][+my] smartphone. → I like [-my][+mine].
7. This is [-theirs][+their] Ferrari. → This is [-their][+theirs].
8. Where is [+your][-yours] key? → Where's [-your][+yours]?
9. Can I use [-hers][+her] mobile? → Can I use [+hers][-her]?
10. Is this [-ours][+our] present? → Is this [+ours][-our]?

bit.body:
1. Is that {0} pen? → Is it {1}?
2. This is {2} house. → It's {3}.
3. They're {4} children. → They're {5}.
4. She lost {6} book. → She lost {7}.
5. These are {8} folders. → These are {9}.
6. I like {10} smartphone. → I like {11}.
7. This is {12} Ferrari. → This is {13}.
8. Where is {14} key? → Where's {15}?
9. Can I use {16} mobile? → Can I use {17}?
10. Is this {18} present? → Is this {19}?
bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben die richtige Form aus – **Possessivbegleiter** oder **Possessivpronomen**.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218320]
[%Nr. 3132]
[!Steht im Satz oder in der Frage ein **Possessivbegleiter** oder ein **Possessivpronomen**? Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.]

1. This is Emma, my sister. → [+Possessivbegleiter][-Possessivpronomen]
2. Is this T-shirt hers? → [-Possessivbegleiter][+Possessivpronomen]
3. This is not William's tablet. This is her tablet. → [+Possessivbegleiter][-Possessivpronomen]
4. Is there an interactive whiteboard in our classroom? → [+Possessivbegleiter][-Possessivpronomen]
5. Sorry, I don't have my homework. → [+Possessivbegleiter][-Possessivpronomen]
6. Whose trainers are those? Are those yours, Linda? → [-Possessivbegleiter][+Possessivpronomen]
7. Is that your Playstation? → [+Possessivbegleiter][-Possessivpronomen]
8. They think everything is theirs. → [-Possessivbegleiter][+Possessivpronomen]
9. This sandwich is better than mine. → [-Possessivbegleiter][+Possessivpronomen]
10. He took Anna's hand in his. → [-Possessivbegleiter][+Possessivpronomen]

bit.instruction: Steht im Satz oder in der Frage ein **Possessivbegleiter** oder ein **Possessivpronomen**? Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218321]
[%Nr. 3166]
[!Setze das Personalpronomen in Klammern entweder in der **Subjektform**, der **Objektform**, als **Possessivbegleiter** oder als **Possessivpronomen** ein.]

0. Can [_you][@example] and [_your][@example] sister come to the meeting? __(you)__
1. We can phone my grandma and ask [_her][!she].
2. Are [_they][!they] your friends?
3. [_She][!she] is working on [_her][!she] presentation.
4. Excuse [_me][!I], can [_I][!I] ask a question?
5. [_They][!they] can ride [_their][!they] skateboards.
6. [_He] is [_his][!he] friend.
7. This is not [_my][!I] jacket, [_mine][!I] was blue.
8. [_She][!she] bought it for [_her][!she].
9. These two cats are [_ours][!we].
10. [_They][!they] don't eat potatoes because [_they][!they] don't like [_them][!they].

bit.body:
0. Can {0} and {1} sister come to the meeting? __(you)__
1. We can phone my grandma and ask {2}.
2. Are {3} your friends?
3. {4} is working on {5} presentation.
4. Excuse {6}, can {7} ask a question?
5. {8} can ride {9} skateboards.
6. {10} is {11} friend.
7. This is not {12} jacket, {13} was blue.
8. {14} bought it for {15}.
9. These two cats are {16}.
10. {17} don't eat potatoes because {18} don't like {19}.
bit.instruction: Setze das Personalpronomen in Klammern entweder in der **Subjektform**, der **Objektform**, als **Possessivbegleiter** oder als **Possessivpronomen** ein.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218322]
[%Nr. 3152]
[!Wähle das richtige Reflexivpronomen aus den Vorgaben aus.

bitmark:

8. I was so shocked, I could hardly [+move][-move myself].
9. He often [+remembers][-remembers himself] the trip to China.
10. We can't [+imagine][-imagine ourselves] living without electricity.

bit.instruction: Wähle das richtige Relativpronomen **who**, **which** oder **whose** aus den Vorgaben aus.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218325]
[%Nr. 3158]
[!Setze die Relativpronemen **who**, **which** oder **whose** ein. Wenn kein Wort eingesetzt werden muss, dann tipp ein **x**.]

0. Peter is the boy [_who][@example] rides the blue bike.
1. This is the boy [_who] had an accident.
2. Yesterday I saw a car [_which] was really old.
3. Mandy is the girl [_x] I met on Friday.
4. I haven't seen Frank, [_whose] brother is five, for a long time now.
5. The robber stole the car [_x] the lady parked in front of the supermarket.
6. This is the man [_whose] house is on fire.
7. Can I talk to the girl [_who]  is sitting on the bench?
8. The book [_x] you gave me is great.
9. She likes hamburgers [_which] are hot.
10. Bill Clinton, [_who] was President of the USA, has only one daughter.

5. The robber stole the car {5} the lady parked in front of the supermarket.
6. This is the man {6} house is on fire.
7. Can I talk to the girl {7}  is sitting on the bench?
8. The book {8} you gave me is great.
9. She likes hamburgers {9} are hot.
10. Bill Clinton, {10} was President of the USA, has only one daughter.

bitmark:

[%Nr. 3146]
[!Wähle aus den folgenden Pronomen das richtige aus.
**myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves** oder **each other**.]

1. Sandra and Angela lost [-myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][+each other] in front of the stadium.
2. My friends enjoyed [-myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][+themselves][-each other] very much at the concert.
3. Tim repaired his car [-myself][-yourself][+himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][-each other].
4. We helped [-myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][+each other] with our report.
5. People often give [-myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][+each other] presents at Christmas.
6. I bought [+myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][-each other] a new camera.
7. Chris, did you do the maths homework [-myself][+yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][-each other]?
8. They looked at [-myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][+each other] and smiled.
9. Ron and Tom often write e-mails to [-myself][-yourself][-himself][-herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][+each other] because they're good friends.
10. Ann only thinks of [-myself][-yourself][-himself][+herself][-itself][-ourselves][-yourselves][-themselves][-each other]. She's selfish.

bit.body:
1. Sandra and Angela lost {0} in front of the stadium.
2. My friends enjoyed {1} very much at the concert.
3. Tim repaired his car {2}.
4. We helped {3} with our report.
5. People often give {4} presents at Christmas.
6. I bought {5} a new camera.
7. Chris, did you do the maths homework {6}?

Wähle aus den folgenden Pronomen das richtige aus.
**myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves** oder **each other**.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218327]
[%Nr. 3148]
[!Schreibe das richtige Pronomen in die Lücke. Suche dir aus den folgenden Reflexivpronomen das passende aus:
**myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves** oder **each other**]

0. I cut [_myself][@example] this morning.
1. Mike and Bill know [_each other] quite well.
2. Sue and Lisa haven't seen [_each other] for ages.
3. Peggy and Jane made this delicious cake [_themselves].
4. Grandpa constructed this desk [_himself].
5. Can we sell the things we made [_ourselves]?
6. The little girl can already ride the tricycle [_herself].
7. Laura and Betty are helping [_each other] with their homework.
8. Some people only think of [_themselves].
9. John and his girlfriend are still angry. They're not talking to [_each other].
10. Does the laptop switch off [_itself] automatically?

bit.body:

1. Mike and Bill know {1} quite well.
2. Sue and Lisa haven't seen {2} for ages.
3. Peggy and Jane made this delicious cake {3}.
4. Grandpa constructed this desk {4}.
5. Can we sell the things we made {5}?
6. The little girl can already ride the tricycle {6}.
7. Laura and Betty are helping {7} with their homework.
8. Some people only think of {8}.
9. John and his girlfriend are still angry. They're not talking to {9}.
10. Does the laptop switch off {10} automatically?
bit.instruction:

**myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves** oder **each other**

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218328]
[%Nr. 3150]
[!Wähle das richtige Reflexivpronomen aus und schreibe es in die Lücke.]

0. Walter and Fred – stop talking to [_each other][@example]!
1. I can carry this heavy box [_myself].
2. Marcus cut [_himself] while he was preparing supper.
3. I have been teaching [_myself] Russian for five years.
4. Has Yvonne hurt [_herself]?
5. Patrick and Stephen, help [_yourselves] to some tea, please.
6. The Pope [_himself] visited our church.
7. Don't burn [_yourself]! The oven is terribly hot.
8. "Claire, who wrote the theatre programme for your school?" - Claire: "I wrote it [_myself]."
9. We're sorry, we don't know the way to the castle [_ourselves].
10. Are Doreen and George married to [_each other].

2. Marcus cut {2} while he was preparing supper.
3. I have been teaching {3} Russian for five years.
4. Has Yvonne hurt {4}?
5. Patrick and Stephen, help {5} to some tea, please.
6. The Pope {6} visited our church.
7. Don't burn {7}! The oven is terribly hot.
8. "Claire, who wrote the theatre programme for your school?" - Claire: "I wrote it {8}."
9. We're sorry, we don't know the way to the castle {9}.
10. Are Doreen and George married to {10}.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218329]
[%Nr. 3174]
[!Wähle das richtige Personalpronomen aus und vervollständige so die Sätze nach den deutschen Vorgaben.]

1. **Sie** lebt in Liverpool.
[_She] lives in Liverpool.
2. **Sie** spielen jeden Tag Fußball.
[_They] play football every day.
3. Frau Jones - können **Sie** mir bitte helfen?
Ms Jones - Can [_you] help me, please?
4. **Sie** können sonntags spät ausfstehen.
[_They] can get up late on Sundays.
5. Ist das deine Tasche? - Ist **sie** neu?
Is this your bag? - Is [_it] new?
6. Hast du Donna gesehen? - Wo ist **sie**?
Have you seen Donna? - Where is [_she]?
7. Hast du Mary und Linda gesehen? - Wo sind **sie**?
Have you seen Mary and Linda? - Where are [_they]?
8. Sind **Sie** Frau Wilson?
Are [_you] Ms. Wilson?
9. Wo sind die Bücher? - **Sie** sind hier.
Where are the books? - [_They] are here.
10. Jack kommt aus einer kleinen Stadt. - **Sie ist** am Meer.
Jack comes from a small town. [_It] is near the sea.

Is this your bag? - Is {4} new?
6. Hast du Donna gesehen? - Wo ist **sie**?
Have you seen Donna? - Where is {5}?
7. Hast du Mary und Linda gesehen? - Wo sind **sie**?
Have you seen Mary and Linda? - Where are {6}?
8. Sind **Sie** Frau Wilson?
Are {7} Ms. Wilson?
9. Wo sind die Bücher? - **Sie** sind hier.
Where are the books? - {8} are here.
10. Jack kommt aus einer kleinen Stadt. - **Sie ist** am Meer.

{4} {5} a cat.

{6} {7} to music.

{8} {9} tennis.

{10} {11} under the shower.

{12} {13} by bus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218331]
[%Nr. 3172]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus und vervollständige so die Sätze/Fragen.]

This is Amy. [-It][+She][-They] [-am][-are][+is] 12.
2. Das ist meine Jacke. Sie ist blau.
This is my jacket. [+It][-She][-They][-am][-are][+is] blue.
3. Er lebt in den Bergen. Sie sind schön.

9. Das ist Frau Meyer. Sie ist sehr freundlich.
This is Ms. Meyer. [-It][+She][-They] [-am][-are][+is] very friendly.
10. Wo sind Gerry und John? Sind sie zu Hause?
Where are Gerry and John? [-Am][+Are][-Is] [-it][-she][+they] at home?

This is Amy. {0} {1} 12.

This is my jacket. {2} blue.
3. Er lebt in den Bergen. Sie sind schön.
He lives in the mountains. {3} {4} nice.

Do you know Olivia? {5} {6} is from Spain.

My school is big. {7} {8} on a hill.

Lenny has two sisters. {9} {10} tall.
7. Wir haben zwei Autos. Sie sind schwarz.
We have two cars. {11} {12} black.

bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus und vervollständige so die Sätze/Fragen.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218332]
[%Nr. 3136]
[!Steht im Satz oder in der Frage ein **Subjektpronomen** oder ein **Objektpronomen**. Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.]

1. **I** am from Berlin. → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen]
2. Can Mr Henderson help **me**? → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen]
3. **We** live in London. → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen]
4. This book is for **her**. → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen]
5. **He** is not at school. → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen]
6. This present is for **us**. → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen]
7. This is a new house. **It** is blue. → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen]
8. Where are **you** from? → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen]
9. Don't ask **them**! → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen]
10. The children can see **you**. → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen]

bit.instruction: Steht im Satz oder in der Frage ein **Subjektpronomen** oder ein **Objektpronomen**. Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218333]
[%Nr. 3138]
[!Ist das unterstrichene Wort ein **Subjektpronomen**, ein **Objektpronomen** oder ein **Possessivbegleiter**? Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.]

1. **She** likes playing football. → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter]
2. **My** name is Greg. → [-Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][+Possessivbegleiter]
3. Tim can see **her** in the supermarket. → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter]
4. What's **your** favourite food? → [-Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][+Possessivbegleiter]
5. **He** can see Emily in the shop. → [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter]
6. Mary can see **our** car near the school. → [-Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][+Possessivbegleiter]
7. Jack often texts **him**. → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter]
8. Mr Brown is **their** teacher. → [-Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][+Possessivbegleiter]
9. Don't forget **it**! → [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter]
10. Why don't **you** [+Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter] give **him** [-Subjektpronomen][+Objektpronomen][-Possessivbegleiter] **his** [-Subjektpronomen][-Objektpronomen][+Possessivbegleiter] present?

bit.instruction: Ist das unterstrichene Wort ein **Subjektpronomen**, ein **Objektpronomen** oder ein **Possessivbegleiter**? Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218334]
[%Nr. 3160]
[!Wähle aus den Vorgaben entweder **this, that, these oder those** aus.]

1. Look at [+this][-that][-these][-those] newspaper here.
2. [-This][-That][+These][-Those] are my grandparents, and [-this][-that][-these][+those] people over there are my friend's grandparents.
3. [-This][+That][-These][-Those] building over there is the Chrysler Building.
4. [+This][-That][-These][-Those] is my mobile phone and [-this][+that][-these][-those] is your mobile phone on the shelf over there.
5. [-This][-That][+These][-Those] photos here are much better than [-this][-that][-these][+those] photos on the book.
6. [-This][+That][-These][-Those] was a great evening.
7. Are [-this][-that][+these][-those] your pencils here?
8. [-This][+That][-These][-Those] bottle over there is empty.
9. [-This][-That][-These][+Those] bricks over there are for your chimney.
10. John, take [+this][-that][-these][-those] folder and put it on the desk over there.

bit.body:
1. Look at {0} newspaper here.
2. {1} are my grandparents, and {2} people over there are my friend's grandparents.
3. {3} building over there is the Chrysler Building.
4. {4} is my mobile phone and {5} is your mobile phone on the shelf over there.
5. {6} photos here are much better than {7} photos on the book.
6. {8} was a great evening.
7. Are {9} your pencils here?
8. {10} bottle over there is empty.
9. {11} bricks over there are for your chimney.
10. John, take {12} folder and put it on the desk over there.
bit.instruction: Wähle aus den Vorgaben entweder **this, that, these oder those** aus.

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218335]
[%Nr. 3140]
[!Entscheide, ob __this__ oder __these__ eingesetzt werden muss.]

4. Could you help me with [-this][+these] boxes?
5. Whose copies are [-this][+these]?
6. I have just bought [+this][-these] old car.
7. [+This][-These] man has three children.
8. I like [-this][+these] jeans.
9. Hi, [+this][-these] is Gerry speaking.
10. [-This][+These] two people are my friends.

2. {1} are our bags.
3. Whose book is {2}?
4. Could you help me with {3} boxes?
5. Whose copies are {4}?
6. I have just bought {5} old car.
7. {6} man has three children.
8. I like {7} jeans.
9. Hi, {8} is Gerry speaking.
10. {9} two people are my friends.
bit.instruction: Entscheide, ob __this__ oder __these__ eingesetzt werden muss.

bitmark:
[.cloze:bitmark--]
[@id:218336]
[%Nr. 3142]
[!Schreibe den Satz/die Frage noch einmal und **ersetze** this durch these oder umgekehrt. Beachte, dass auch Substantive (Singular/Plural) zu ändern sind.]

0. Do you like this photo?
[_Do you like these photos][@example]?
1. This phone looks old.
[_These phones look old].
2. This car is very fast.
[_These cars are very fast].
3. These children study at our school.
[_This child studies at our school].
4. I like these old books.
[_I like this old book].
5. This burger tastes good.
[_These burgers taste good].
6. These bags are very nice.
[_This bag is very nice].
7. Is this your pencil?
[_Are these your pencils]?
8. What is this?
[_What are these]?
9. Whose keys are these?
[_Whose key is this]?
10. He can't read these words.
[_He can't read this word].

bit.body:
0. Do you like this photo?
{0}?
1. This phone looks old.
{1}.
2. This car is very fast.
{2}.
3. These children study at our school.
{3}.
4. I like these old books.
{4}.
5. This burger tastes good.
{5}.
6. These bags are very nice.
{6}.
7. Is this your pencil?
{7}?
8. What is this?
{8}?
9. Whose keys are these?
{9}?
10. He can't read these words.
{10}.
bit.instruction: Schreibe den Satz/die Frage noch einmal und **ersetze** this durch these oder umgekehrt. Beachte, dass auch Substantive (Singular/Plural) zu ändern sind.

solutions: This child studies at our school

bitmark:
[.multiple-choice-text:bitmark--]
[@id:218337]
[%Nr. 3144]
[!Entscheide ob **who** oder **whose** einzusetzen ist. Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.]

1. He knows the girl [+who][-whose] has three dogs.
2. This is Gerry [+who][-whose] saw a rabbit in our garden.
3. This is John [-who][+whose] laptop was stolen this morning.
4. Mrs Miller, [-who][+whose] father is a painter, came to New York in 1950.
5. I talked to the man [+who][-whose] lives in High Street.
6. James Watt was an inventor [-who][+whose] ideas changed the world.
7. Doris is the lady [+who][-whose] got the first prize.
8. Ethan, [+who][-whose] is Isabella's boyfriend, plays badminton.
9. What do you call someone [+who][-whose] lives in Texas?  
10. The Smiths, [-who][+whose] son went to the USA, are selling their house.

bit.body:
1. He knows the girl {0} has three dogs.
2. This is Gerry {1} saw a rabbit in our garden.
3. This is John {2} laptop was stolen this morning.
4. Mrs Miller, {3} father is a painter, came to New York in 1950.
5. I talked to the man {4} lives in High Street.
6. James Watt was an inventor {5} ideas changed the world.
7. Doris is the lady {6} got the first prize.
8. Ethan, {7} is Isabella's boyfriend, plays badminton.
9. What do you call someone {8} lives in Texas?  
10. The Smiths, {9} son went to the USA, are selling their house.
bit.instruction: Entscheide ob **who** oder **whose** einzusetzen ist. Wähle aus den Vorgaben aus.
